Beware of group thinking
Lead the dynamic team

core.title: Leadership with emotional intelligence
core.description:
How do leaders and managers develop their skills in order to ensure good performance, without losing sight of people’s expectations? Are there dimensions that can make the difference?

In this pill, we will focus on emotional intelligence as the key to success in terms of leadership and performance. We'll talk about how important is to have relationship-oriented leaders and managers and we'll discover which skills are needed to manage emotional intelligence.

metadata.summary: The wellbeing and performance of staff depends on emotionally intelligent leadership.
learning_outcomes: Discover the dimensions of emotional intelligence.
Develop a mindful approach.
Prepare yourself for understanding rather than judgement.

core.title: Leadership for change
core.description:
Digital transformation, internationalisation, and mergers are only a few ways to change organisations. How can leaders and managers prepare organisations to change? What are the main skills needed?

In this pill, we will talk about changes as a constant condition in an organisation’s life. We will learn how important it is to face change with a project that considers organisational, cultural, and human factors. We will see the topics and situations that leaders and managers must face with responsibility and maturity, when living "in" the change and managing processes “of” change.

metadata.summary: Prepare, orient and empower colleagues to help them navigate through change.
learning_outcomes: How to tackle and manage organisational change.
Understanding what skills leaders and managers must deploy to deal with transformation.
Practise resilient leadership.

core.title: Leadership for Engagement
core.description:
When can it be said that an employee is engaged? Which factors contribute to increasing the level of involvement of people in organisations? How important is the leadership style?

This pill explains what is meant by engagement and its implications in the workplace. We will discover the indicators required to understand if and how much our employees are genuinely engaged about what they do and we will see how significant the impact of managers and leaders is on their involvement.

metadata.summary: Stimulating a sense of shared purpose through engaged leadership.
learning_outcomes: Finding out when an employee can be told to be engaged.
Understanding the role of leaders and managers in increasing the level of involvement of employees.
Knowing the levers required to engage people.

core.title: Leadership focussed on staff development
core.description:
How much energy do we put into enabling colleagues to develop and grow? Do we tend towards a command and control management approach, or do we act as leader-coaches who invest in enhancing the autonomy and development of others? Do we consider ourselves as credible reference points for the teams and individuals we guide?

In this course, we will consider together how to look after those who work with us, in order to stimulate their growth and help them to improve their performance. We'll see which style characterises leaders and managers capable of "bringing out the best" in their colleagues, by reflecting on trust, dialogue and listening. We'll focus on the importance of leadership by example for building trust and inspiring credibility in those who work with us.

metadata.summary: Be a reference point and a performance catalyst for your colleagues
learning_outcomes: Stimulate the growth of your colleagues.
Understand people through listening.
Believe in them by trusting them.

core.title: Leadership Styles
core.description:
Each style of leadership has pros and cons, and the style you adopt may change depending on the situation. This course will look at the main leadership styles, which will help you develop your own personal leadership style and become a more effective leader.

This lesson forms part of the Management Skills Award course.

metadata.summary: Learn about the different styles of leadership to help you develop a personal style that works for you
learning_outcomes: Four leadership styles that are used in business today
The advantages, disadvantages, and suitable scenarios of each style

core.title: Leadership Development
core.description:
Very few leaders are born with the qualities required to inspire and lead others. Most leaders are built—through personal effort, lots of introspection, and assistance from mentors and other leaders. In this course, you’ll learn the six characteristics that set effective leaders apart. You’ll discover the differences between managing and leading, and when to do each. And you’ll find out how to create a plan that will help you move from simply managing results to setting vision and leading others.


Accreditation

0.25 hours, Continuing Education Units (CEU) from the Society for Human Resource Management (SHRM)

0.25 hours, Continuing Education Units (CEU) from the HR Certificate Institute (HRCI)

metadata.summary: Recognize the differences between managing and leading.
learning_outcomes: Differentiate between managing and leading
Create leadership development action plan

core.title: Lead with Kindness: Fundamentals Why Lead With Kindness (Part 1 of 5)
core.description:
Lead with Kindness is all about turning the tables from the misconception that "leading with kindness is weak" to the new workplace reality that "leading with kindness is strong." It is a journey of discovering the tools that will assist you in becoming an inspirational leader for the future of work—today! 

In this course, you will understanding what the main components of leading with kindness are, and looking at the impact of kind leadership on self-awareness, empathy & mindset.

Identifying the benefits of leading with kindness for high performance.

learning_outcomes: Define the main components of leading with kindness
Kind leadership impact: self-awareness, empathy & mindset
Identify the benefits of leading with kindness for high performance
Understand the connection between productivity and kind leadership
Identify leaders who role-model kind leadership

core.title: Lead with Kindness: Focus on Valuing Differences (Part 3 of 5)
core.description:
Leading with Kindness is all about turning the tables from the misconception that "leading with kindness is weak" to the new workplace reality that "leading with kindness is strong." It is a journey of discovering the tools that will assist you in becoming an inspirational leader for the future of work—today!

Valuing differences creates a work environment where people can and want to do their best. Working effectively in this diverse world starts with self-awareness–considering how you handle bias, poor treatment, and conflict, and demonstrating that you value others. To be effective, you will not ignore the differences–you will understand, embrace, accommodate, and encourage them.

Valuing differences will help you learn and benefit from the wealth of knowledge and experience that diversity brings. It opens doors to new ways of thinking and new opportunities for building the success of the organization.

learning_outcomes: Understand where our differences come from: essential elements that make us different
Identify different ways in which individuals make an impact and contribution in leading and in teams
Apply an understanding of differences in how teams perform

core.title: Lead with Kindness: Focus on Purposeful Communication (Part 4 of 5)
core.description:
When done well, leadership communication inspires trust and positive change. Good communication is a core leadership function and a key characteristic of a good leader. Effective communication and effective leadership are closely intertwined.

As a leader, you need to be a skilled communicator in countless relationships at the organizational level, in communities and groups, and sometimes on a global scale in order to achieve results through others. Here in this course we will be covering all these and understand the importance of communication.

learning_outcomes: Understand the elements that make effective communication work
Identify the top three communication skills for leading with kindness
Develop listening skills for kind leaders
Practice effective feedback skills
Prepare to speak with impact

core.title: Lead with Kindness: Focus on Holistic Well-Being (Part 2 of 5)
core.description:
Leading with Kindness is all about turning the tables from the misconception that "leading with kindness is weak" to the new workplace reality that "leading with kindness is strong." It is a journey of discovering the tools that will assist you in becoming an inspirational leader for the future of work—today!

Holistic well-being includes body, mind, social, and spirit. The human body is interconnected; our physical body depends on our mental state and vice versa. Your social support influences your mental well-being.

In this course, we will clarify the connection between well-being and leading with kindness and identifying the benefits of a holistic well-being dimension for leadership. Discover strategies to apply well-being initiatives as part of a regular kind leadership practice, in order to build trust and psychological safety.

learning_outcomes: Analyze the connection between well-being and leading with kindness
Identify the benefits of a holistic well-being dimension
Apply well-being initiatives as part of a regular kind leadership practice
Build trust and psychological safety

core.title: LEAD with Empathy – Interactive
core.description:
(Updated Oct 2024)

LEAD with Empathy is a course that will help all leaders to focus on four core leadership soft skills. Great leaders listen, they have empathy, they ask questions and they give clear direction. Psychologist Eve Ash outlines the ways leaders can learn how to LEAD.

 

Once this course is completed you will have learned to implement the LEAD formula, beginning by listening well and responding with empathy to what people are saying. You will recognize how showing genuine interest and compassion, not talking in clichés, builds trust. You will have learned to ask for people’s input and keep an open mind on topics and policies. And you will know that people will follow with confidence when you provide clear direction.

 

Learning Objectives

  • Use the four key skills of the LEAD formula to improve your leadership skills
  • Listen carefully to become a very good listener
  • Empathize – respond with care, interest and compassion
  • Ask for input as a means of staying on track
  • Keep an open mind
  • Direct people clearly so they have confidence in following you

core.title: Kurt Lewin’s 3 Stages of Change Model
core.description:
Kurt Lewin a German-American psychologist, defined himself and his contributions within three lenses of analysis: applied research, action research, and group communication were his major offerings. One of the Cornerstone models for understanding organizational change was developed by him and is referred to as "Kurt Lewin's three-stages of Change."

This model breaks into three-stages: Unfreeze, Transition, and Refreeze. In the "Unfreeze" stage, an organization prepares for the change. In the "Transition" stage, the change takes place and in the "Refreeze" stage, the change becomes solidified as the new norm.

Accreditation

0.25 hours, Continuing Education Units (CEU) from the Society for Human Resource Management (SHRM)

0.25 hours, Continuing Education Units (CEU) from the HR Certificate Institute (HRCI)

metadata.summary: Recognize why communication is important in the transition stage.
learning_outcomes: Describe the need for change
Identify the three stages of Kurt Lewin’s change model
List the activities in the unfreezing stage
Explain why communication is important in the transition stage
Explain the importance of refreezing

core.title: Kotter's 8 Step Change Model
core.description:
Kotter's 8-Step Change Model was created by Harvard University Professor, John Kotter. He perceived the change process as having 8 essential steps.

The 8 Essential Steps in this model are:
  • Create a sense of urgency for change
  • Build a coalition for change Form a vision for change
  • Communicate the vision for change
  • Remove barriers to change
  • Generate quick wins for the change
  • Stay persistent with the change
  • Make the change permanent

Accreditation

0.25 hours, Continuing Education Units (CEU) from the Society for Human Resource Management (SHRM)

0.25 hours, Continuing Education Units (CEU) from the HR Certificate Institute (HRCI)

metadata.summary: Understand what leaders can do to make the change successful and describe Kotter’s 8-step change model.
learning_outcomes: Describe Kotter’s 8-step change model
Explain what leaders can do to make the change successful

core.title: Keys to set up a remote team
core.description:
Course Description

Leo is standing near the coffee machine. He looks very worried and he’s talking to himself when Shelly, his colleague arrives.

This course will cover:

  • Forming a successful remote team
  • The four phases of the Tuckman team development model:
  1. Forming,
  2. Storming,
  3. Norming, and
  4. Performing
  • Defining their characteristics
  • Using the right levers in order to succeed in each of the four phases

Time to Complete

15 Minutes

metadata.summary: Remote teams are growing in popularity and are an effective way of conducting a wide variety of projects. This course will cover the basics that you need to know to set up a successful remote team in your organisation. You will learn about the four stages of the Tuckman team development model and discover how you can apply these to your own organisation.
learning_outcomes: The four phases of the Tuckman team development model
A framework to apply the model in your own organisation
How to define the characteristics of successful remote teams

core.title: Kaizen Introduction
core.description:
Lean Kaizen events, also known as Kaizen Blitz or Rapid Improvement Workshops, are a systematic approach to identifying and eliminating problems in a short period of time. A popular Business Improvement method for organisations around the world, they are proven to increase efficiency and ultimately save businesses time and money.

 

Target Audience

Anyone with an interest in Lean or improving processes or projects.

 

Business Outcomes

Understanding what Kaizen is, and how to improve your business.

learning_outcomes: Have a strong understanding of Kaizen
Be confident discussing and championing the method
Be able to identify processes that would benefit from a Kaizen event
Know how to support Kaizen initiatives in an organisation

core.title: KEEP Promises – Interactive
core.description:
(Updated Oct 2024)

KEEP Promises is a course that teaches learners to be develop four KEEP skills that everyone relies on. There is something reassuring about a person who KEEPs promises. Psychologist Eve Ash explores this special personality everyone admires: Keen, Explicit, Efficient and Proud.

 

Once this course is completed you will have learned the power prompt and reliable – someone who gets things done with a minimum of fuss and negativity. You will be armed with the four KEEP skills to ensure a team is humming and delivering efficiently. You will enjoy being keen – determined, committed, on the ball and explicit – clarifying and agreeing on expectations. You will find ways to manage time and tasks so you are efficient, and you will take pride in doing your work well.

 

Learning Objectives

  • Discover what it takes to KEEP promises
  • Be Keen – be determined with the right attitude
  • Be explicit – clarify and agree on expectations
  • Be efficient – track progress, manage time and be task-focused
  • Be proud – enjoy completing work properly and in full

core.title: Introduction to Emotional Intelligence_1
core.description:
You’ve leveraged your education, professional experience, hard work, and business abilities to get to this point in your career. Now you’re responsible for leading a team in achieving your firm’s target goals and objectives. Did you know that there’s another skill that will be critical to your continued success and advancement? It’s called Emotional Intelligence (EQ), and it’s a big business topic these days.

 

Accreditation

0.25 hours, Continuing Education Units (CEU) from the Society for Human Resource Management (SHRM)

0.25 hours, Continuing Education Units (CEU) from the HR Certificate Institute (HRCI)

core.description: What coaching is and what it isn’t, why coaching is one of the most powerful development solutions available as well as uncovering the significant benefits of coaching within an organisation.

core.title: Intrinsic Vs Extrinsic Motivation
core.description:
Employees working in an organization bring a level of enthusiasm and energy to the work they do in the organization. They are committed and creative in their approach. This energy is crucial for any organizational success, and it is termed as emotional motivation. The factors influencing this energy level can be either intrinsic or extrinsic. In this lesson, you will learn about both intrinsic motivation and extrinsic motivation and how to leverage them. How do you motivate your team to do their best? You give them the tools, trust, and time to make their jobs personal. You provide enough challenge for them to work at facilitating better, but not so hard that they become discouraged. Help them connect with their work and give them a reason to work, which is beyond the paycheck.


Accreditation

0.25 hours, Continuing Education Units (CEU) from the Society for Human Resource Management (SHRM)

0.25 hours, Continuing Education Units (CEU) from the HR Certificate Institute (HRCI)

metadata.summary: Understand the challenges of using extrinsic motivation.
learning_outcomes: Explain the challenges of using extrinsic motivation
Learn the three methods of intrinsic motivation: autonomy, mastery, and purpose

core.description:
This course explores the art of influencing and will teach you how to understand others and communicate effectively in order to gain support. Learning from effective influencers and reflecting on your own strengths and weaknesses, the course will help you become a confident and successful influencer.

 

Who is this course for?

 

Those looking to influence others or understand how people are influence ﻿

Individuals wanting to improve their personal development skillset.

 

This course consists of two parts. Here is the second part.

learning_outcomes: Understand how to influence others to change behaviours.

Explore how people are influenced.

core.title: Inclusive Meetings
core.description:
When was the last time you participated in a meeting where everyone felt empowered to share their thoughts and opinions freely?

Meetings are probably the most common and critical forum where people can collaborate and challenge each other. When all team members are actively involved and encouraged to contribute, a wider range of ideas, insights, and solutions can emerge. This diversity of thought enhances problem-solving capabilities, encourages innovation, and leads to more comprehensive and well-rounded decision-making.

In this module, we’ll explore practical strategies for facilitating inclusive team meetings, going beyond mere participation to embrace each individual's unique perspectives, ideas and contributions.

metadata.summary: Leverage diversity, encourage constructive friction and structure meetings for inclusion.
learning_outcomes: Leverage diversity in team meetings
Encourage constructive friction
Structure team meetings for greater inclusion

core.title: Inclusive Leadership
core.description:
Welcome, leaders. You've enrolled in this course to get a better understanding about inclusivity, and how to cultivate it within your organisation. The concept of inclusivity can seem a little fuzzy and abstract at the best of times, so we've done our best to demystify it and give you some great tactics that you can use to grow and nurture an inclusive culture. Everybody can do their bit to create an inclusive environment — nobody's excluded.

 

Learning Objectives

The Inclusive Leader's Playbook course will help you understand:
• The difference between diversity and inclusion.
• What unconscious biases are and how to identify and address your own.
• How to cultivate an inclusive, psychologically safe environment that allows diversity to thrive.

core.description: Every day at work we have to make judgments about the situations we encounter– forecasts or assessments, for example. The problem is that human judgment may be subject to many errors and affect the decisions we make. Some of our judgments are impaired by bias, and others by noise. In this course, you will learn more about these errors and how you can improve your judgment.

core.title: Impact of emotions in the workplace - Part B
core.description:
Emotions play an important role in the workplace. They affect our daily life our reactions to certain situations and our interactions with other coworkers. They play a role in team success but also in stressful situations and conflict. In the latter cases emotions give rise to power struggles and may even lead to crises. In managing emotions and conflict you can obtain better individual and group performance.

This course will cover:

  • Developing your emotional balance.
  • Resolving simple conflicts.

Target Audience

Anyone who wants to develop high-quality human relationships within the workplace.

Prerequisites

It is recommended that you first work through Part A of this course.

Accreditation

PMI accreditation: earn 0.5 PDU points from PMI.

How to use emotions to improve your relationships with others and to resolve conflict

And that's not all: shared feedback enriches relationships at work and increases the company’s learning capacity. In this course, you will acquire a number of simple techniques for giving and receiving feedback with benevolence and efficiency and for strengthening the bonds within the team. core.title: How to Say No Without Saying NO!
core.description:
It's not just people pleasers that find it difficult to say "No". We all do. Depending on the situation, the person, the reason. We get into sticky situations, we have something to lose, we don't want to disappoint, make others feel bad, and a myriad of other reasons. It costs us our mental and physical health to say yes when we want to say "NO!".

This course takes illuminates why it's in your best interest and the other person's best interest for you to say "No" when it's feasible and HOW to powerfully say it without saying it, in a way that is suitable and effective for both parties.

metadata.summary: earn to master the art of interpersonal tact, and saying "No" without saying "No"
learning_outcomes: How to say "No" without using the word "No" when appropriate
Learn how to shift your thinking so that it becomes effortless to say no and pay attention to your needs while also accomplishing what others may want.
How your help people by saying "No" WITHOUT saying "No"

core.title: How to Manage Change Effectively – Interactive
core.description:
(Updated Nov 2024)

How to Manage Change Effectively is a course designed to make sure change is implemented smoothly and effectively. Managing change is an important skill that people throughout an organization need to add to their resumes. Change sometimes happens for reasons out of our control and sometimes we can plan a change, and inevitably is often stressful and frightening, so we often resist it.

In this course psychologist Peter Quarry explains how we can learn to manage change successfully and helps others manage change. We develop agility and resilience if we manage change effectively.

learning_outcomes: Accept and manage your emotional responses
Find opportunities within changing circumstances
Help others to adapt to challenges
Keep everyone informed when organizational change is inevitable

How to Develop Optimism is a simple course that shows how optimism is a skill you can learn and how you can benefit in your relationships your work and your health. Psychology expert Peter Quarry describes the considerable difference you make to your life once you choose to view events optimistically.

How to Develop Optimism helps learners to cope with life’s challenges in apositive way. Learn to see what can be changed positively in your situation. As Peter Quarry explains when you choose the “glass half full” approach difficulties become markedly easier and your relationships improve.

core.title: HOW TO WRITE A GREAT RESUME FOR ANY ROLE
core.description:
In our guide resumes still rule – make sure yours isn’t rejected we talked about why a resume still plays a vital role in recruitment, now we want to show you how to create one that pushes all the right buttons.

TAKE THE TIME TO MAKE YOUR RESUME PERFECT

Your resume is a marketing document designed to achieve one clear objective: secure an interview. Despite the arrival of new recruitment technologies and methods, a strong resume is still the most commonly requested document in the job search process.

Yet they’re often written in haste because candidates view them as an onerous part of the process. That means spending more time writing yours and thinking carefully about what should be in it, can put you one step ahead of the competition.

There’s no one-size-fits-all way to do it, but there are commonly accepted resume writing rules that everyone should follow. In this guide we share these and help you focus on the right things.

PICK THE BEST STRUCTURE FOR YOU

Resumes are usually in a chronological or functional format.

Chronological resumes are the most common. They list experience by employer, showing the time spent at each, starting with the most recent role. For people looking for work in a similar field to the one they are in, who want to highlight their experience, it’s the one to go for.

A functional resume groups and highlights specific capabilities, bringing together information by skill type rather than employer. This format is useful if you’re considering a career change or have a specific skillset (such as technical, medical or engineering skills) that a potential employer would want to know about in more depth.

KEEP IT SHORT, SWEET AND INSTEP WITH THE INTERNET

Your resume shouldn’t be longer than two A4 pages unless you work in a specific sector that expects more detail (and there aren’t many of those). The objective is to secure an interview, you can expand on the information you’ve provided when you’re there. So be concise.

Also take a bit of time to make sure your online profile complements your resume and creates a positive impression. Check dates align on sites such as LinkedIn – where you can also go into more detail about your experience than on your resume – and hide any social media posts that might damage your personal brand.

TARGET YOUR RESUME

You should have a compelling resume on hand to share with anyone who wants to know more about you. But when you’re applying for a specific job you need to make it as relevant to the role as you can. This means researching the organization you’re applying to, reflecting on the skills and experience they need and shaping your resume to fit with what you think the recruiter wants to see.

If you already have a resume it’ll probably just need small adjustments to draw out the experience most relevant to the position. Imagine you’re the recruiter or hiring manager – what would you want to see and how can you align with that?

When you research the company think about when you’ve worked in that type of environment before. If it is large multi-national organization and that matches your experience, say so. For example:

Experience of navigating and getting things done in a large multi-country, multi-cultural environment.

Having said that, targeting your resume doesn’t mean you should make up skills and experience to fit the role. That’ll trip you up somewhere along the line. Likewise don’t copy and paste large chunks of content from the job advert into your resume, it looks lazy.

DON’T FORGET THE ROBOTS

As we’ve mentioned in other guides, the ease and accessibility the internet has brought to the jobs market has dramatically increased the number of applicants per role. And recruiters are turning to technology for help. This means your resume is likely to be analyzed by an Applicant Tracking System (ATS) or screening robot.

These systems will categorize and rank applicants for their suitability for a role. The top ten or 20 matches will then be screened by a human who will create a shortlist to interview.

An ATS or robot divides a resume into smaller chunks and scans for key words. They’re not perfect but their accuracy is improving and they’re not going away, so you need to write your resume with a robot in mind:

  • Keep your format clean and simple. Remove graphics, images, tables and logos.
  • Use keywords from the job description. But don’t copy and paste the whole thing.
  • Match titles from current and previous roles to those referenced in the job description.
  • Submit in a common format, such as Word or PDF.


NOW, LET’S LOOK AT EACH SECTION OF A CHRONOLOGICAL RESUME IN DETAIL

Your profile or situation summary
If your resume beats the applicant tracking systems (ATS) and finds itself in front of a human, this might be the only section they read. So make it count. Here’s how:

  • Avoid clichés and hyperbole. Keep it factual and concise.
  • Think about what an employer needs. Describe your profession, specialist skills and a couple of professional characteristics.
  • Include key words. A recruiter, and an ATS, will look for these.
  • Avoid common skills. Such as Word, Excel and Powerpoint, unless they have been specifically asked for.
  • Go easy on soft skills. You can demonstrate these at an interview, a resume should highlight hard skills.

Here’s an example of a good summary:

MBA qualified Operations Manager with 10 years of experience in retail banking and insurance. Innovative and practical approach to process re-engineering and a skilled negotiator with strong people management and leadership capabilities. Looking to secure a leadership role in the financial services sector that offers exposure to IT transformation initiatives that improve customer service and efficiency.

Key skills include:

* Operational Improvement * Project Management * Strategic Planning * Leadership Skills * IT Transformation * Risk and Compliance * Stakeholder Management * Budget Management

Education
List education and qualifications in reverse chronological order. If you have applied for a role as an accountant and are a fully qualified chartered accountant (CA) with a degree in accounting, list the CA qualification first and the degree second. Only include relevant qualifications – recruiters looking for accountants don’t need to know you’re also a qualified street dance instructor.

Remember the first half of the first page of your resume is the most important, so if you have more than two items of education you need to include, consider moving them below your work achievements, so they’re not overlooked.

Work history
As with education, detail your current or most recent role first. This works better with an ATS and means your recent relevant experience is most prominent.

Start with your job title, the company name, its location, and your dates of employment including the months. If your company isn’t well known, add a sentence explaining who they are and their size. Now link your skills with your achievements in the role, by showing a positive result followed by how you achieved it. For example:

National Sales Manager

ABC INC. Melbourne, Australia
Jan 2014 – Current

A global bio tech employing 300+ people specializing in drugs for patients suffering life-threatening cases of melanoma and other terminal cancers.

  • Doubled annual revenue for the local affiliate and produced $7M in sales in the first year by conducting a robust territory analysis and implementing a focused sales strategy.
  • Grew the team from four to eight territory managers in 2015 in direct response to expanding the portfolio into both specialists and hospitals.

Personal interests
Lots of people include this section but it’s unlikely to help secure you an interview. In fact, it can be detrimental to your chances if it triggers subconscious bias in a recruiter. If your personal interests have a direct link to the role you are applying for then include them (a passion for photography and art would be useful to a photographer’s assistant) otherwise leave them out.

Awards and affiliations
Only include them if they’re less than three years old, are directly relevant to the role and will be easily recognized by a recruiter.

References
There’s no need to include them or waste space writing ‘available on request’. A recruiter will assume this.

Write, edit and edit again

Once you’ve decided what should be in your resume you need to make sure you deliver it in a way that’s compelling and easy to understand. Always bear in mind:

  • Spelling mistakes are lethal. According to CareerBuilder, 61% of recruiters will automatically reject a resume with typos. Don’t rely on spell check, ask friends to proofread it for you.
  • Don’t overuse adjectives. Filling your resume with terms such as ‘inspirational leader’, ‘highly motivated’, ‘skilled communicator’, ‘pro-active mindset’ won’t impress anyone, in fact they’re more likely to put them off. Instead provide examples of an activity or initiative you were involved in that demonstrates each of these qualities.
  • Ditch company jargon. Use commonly understood industry titles and references. Your company might call human resources ‘people capital’ but an ATS or recruiter might not know what you’re talking about.
  • Be consistent with your tense. Select either first person or third person and stick with it.
  • Use simple formatting. Whatever style and structure you select make it consistent and don’t get too creative. Unnecessary swirls, logos, italics or underlining make it harder for readers to pick out information.
  • Don’t be economical with the truth. As tempting as is to overstate your skills, it’s a waste of everybody’s time if you can’t back it up at an interview.

Now, go back and read it one more time.

FIVE THINGS TO REMEMBER:

  1. Check, re-check and check again for spelling, grammar and layout consistency
  2. Keep it concise. Two pages is usually enough.
  3. Target your resume for specific roles and companies.
  4. Ensure your digital profile aligns with your resume.
  5. Don’t think of it as a chore. This can change your life – it’s worth a little time.

MORE TOOLS AND GUIDES:

  • Check the quality of your resume using an evaluation and scoring tool like Rezscore.com. The report it provides might not be 100% accurate for the country you are in, but it will certainly be a great starting point and give you some guidance on where you could make some improvements.

core.title: GET NOTICED WITH OUR TIPS FOR A GREAT LINKEDIN PROFILE
core.description:
LinkedIn is the dominant professional networking site – it has around 500 million users and is where recruiters often begin their search for new staff – so it goes without saying (but we’ll say it) you need to have a LinkedIn profile. Once you’ve got a great looking LinkedIn profile one you need to make sure it’s working hard for you.

FIND OUT WHY LINKEDIN IS IMPORTANT FOR THE MODERN JOB SEEKER

In this guide we cover the ‘must do’ actions to create a LinkedIn profile that will get you noticed as well as advice on kickstarting your networking activity.

SOME THINGS TO CONSIDER WHEN CREATING YOUR PROFILE

Good recruiters will be proactively searching for talent online, which means devoting time to getting your profile right could cut how long it takes you to find a new position. Employers will often get in touch with suitable candidates on LinkedIn before a job has been advertised or an application made, so you need to make yours stands out. Here are some tips:

Start brilliantly. View your profile as other users would and make sure that everything they can see when they first land on it entices them keep scrolling down.

Perfect your headline. Not only is this at the top of your page (see previous point) your name and headline are what recruiters see when they search for you on LinkedIn or in Google. Unless you manually edit your headline it will default to your current job title and company. Change it to include different industry recognized titles and bring to life what you do. So rather than ‘HR director for NuVenture Ltd’ try: ‘HR director, talent manager, HR leader, change manager, HR business partner, supporting 4,000 employees across North America in the IT services sector’.

Now work on your summary. Also one of first things people see, your summary should be concise but include four to six bullet points of key attributes, skills and experience. It should also bring to life areas of focus and passion.

Mix up your media. Rather than relying on text in the summary, consider including documents you might have written, relevant photos, research papers or articles and videos. LinkedIn’s Professional Portfolio tool can help you.

Keep using keywords. Many recruitment tools and recruiters use keywords when searching the internet for talent. Applying effective search engine optimization tactics to your LinkedIn profile will help people interested in your skills find you. At the very least your keywords should include your industry, location, company names and specialist skills. Ensure your keywords are used frequently and consistently throughout your headline, job titles, summary and skill descriptions.

Do your research. Look at job adverts in your area of expertise and note down the hard skills employers are regularly looking for. Although each advert may be phrased differently, they could be targeting the same skills, so think how one skill can be described in several ways and include them all in your profile if you can. For example, one company might be looking for a human resources professional with recruitment experience, but another might be looking for talent acquisition expertise. In this case, it would be wise to include both as key words and phrases. LinkedIn’s Insights tool can also help you identify important keywords.

Ask contacts for endorsements. Your skills will rank higher in search results, if other people have endorsed you for those skills.

Say cheese. Although you shouldn’t use pictures on your resume, always add one to your LinkedIn profile. Studies have shown profiles with a photo are 30% more likely to be clicked on. If you can, get a headshot taken by a photographer, otherwise choose one of you looking professional rather than a selfie on the beach.

Customize your LinkedIn URL. If you don’t, you’ll be allocated a random mix of letters and numbers that will look messy on your resume. If you can, customize the URL to as close to your full name as possible.

Get recommendations from previous colleagues and managers. If appropriate, ask them to include some of your keywords. You can only ask for recommendations from people who are first degree contacts, offering them one in return is a good way to make it worth their while.

Review your privacy settings. If you’re looking for new career opportunities you should make your profile as public as possible, even if it’s just for the duration of your job hunt. The more you share on LinkedIn the more likely recruiters are to find you. If you are updating your profile with a view to getting a new job it’s worth bearing in mind that your connections, including current colleagues, will be notified of your profile edits unless you turn this feature off.

Consider upgrading to a premium account during your job search. A premium account allows you to connect directly with individuals and gives you access to tools that increase your visibility in searches. It costs around USD $30 per month, unless you’re eligible for a free trial.

NOW, MAKE SURE YOUR PROFILE COMPLEMENTS YOUR RESUME

Your resume should be targeted at the specific job you are applying for, focusing on experience relevant to that position. Your LinkedIn profile, on the other hand, aims to promote your general professional brand. But they should be consistent with each other in terms of dates and roles held.

LinkedIn gives you the chance to expand on details in your resume. You can explain the scope of your current and previous roles, the status and strategic priorities of the businesses, what you focused on and the kind of environments you worked in. In your resume you should focus more on outcomes that demonstrate skills you’ll need for a specific role.

A good recruiter will be reviewing your online profile before committing to an interview or further evaluation, so it’s vital you don’t give them any reasons to doubt you. If an employer looks you up online, you want to make sure that what they see clearly demonstrates who you are and what you can offer. It’s a good idea to keep your social media accounts private just in case there is anything on them that might damage your professional brand.

BE ACTIVE AND BUILD YOUR NETWORK

Just having a great LinkedIn profile may not be enough. You need to engage with like-minded professionals and companies to keep growing your network.

The more connections you have the more often you will appear in search results as a second or third degree connection. One prerequisite of a 100% complete profile is to have at least 50 connections – LinkedIn says a complete profile appears in a search on average 40 times more than an complete one, as well as featuring higher up the results.

If you are setting up your profile for the first time, allow LinkedIn to access your contacts and identify who is already on the site. Also review the ‘people you may know’ suggestions that LinkedIn provides and send an invite to connect where appropriate.

You can also expand your LinkedIn network by:

  • Joining and actively contributing to industry groups. By being an active member of your network, you will be first and foremost in the minds of employers when the time is right.
  • Network offline. Be active in the physical world, meeting people at conferences and industry events and connecting afterwards.
  • Post your activity on LinkedIn so your network can see what events you are attending. If you are hosting one, they may share it with their connections.
  • Be nosy. Look up other people in your industry and compare profiles. Could yours be improved? They are likely to check out your profile in return – if you have a premium account you’ll be able to see who has viewed your profile.
  • Share content. Write or share relevant articles and content and comment on posts within your professional community. If you are consistently appearing in your connections’ feeds they’ll remember you when an opportunity arises.

BUT PAUSE BEFORE YOU START POSTING

Take a moment before promoting yourself online to check your profile is credible and think about how a recruiter might react to a post before posting it. Employers will judge you based on your online activity. But get it right and you might find a job comes to you before anybody else knows about it.

FIVE THINGS TO REMEMBER:

  1. Your LinkedIn profile needs to be current and complete
  2. Add specific keywords and phrases
  3. Treat the first page of your profile as prime real estate
  4. Nail your headline
  5. Keep building your networks

core.title: Feedback Mechanisms
core.description:
About this course: A feedback mechanism provides the means for you to track personal performance. It should be used to improve your performance in the future. If your job involves sales, managing budgets and production, your success can usually be measured in numbers. So, a Feedback Mechanism will be an indicator that highlights your performance in numbers. 
What if you are a leader? Your performance could be judged on more abstract terms such as how your interpersonal skills are evolving. If you are a leader, often the main source of feedback will be through performance reviews and sources of this information will come from your manager and your peers. Keep in mind this feedback promotes personal and professional growth. There may be positive and negative feedback but always keep in mind that these are just our indicators and will help us to improve. Remember also that the feedback mechanism is a two-way process. As a leader you give feedback to your team and you will also encourage your team members to open up and voice their opinions about your leadership. Note that you should always make arrangements to have regular feedback sessions.
Today, we will be learning different ways to obtain feedback on your performance in the workplace and understanding the importance of feedback mechanisms. 
Once the session is completed, you will be able to define the meaning of a feedback mechanism, identify the different ways of getting feedback on performance in the workplace and explain the importance of a feedback mechanisms in leadership and team building.

learning_outcomes: Define the meaning of a feedback mechanism
Identify the different ways of getting feedback on performance in the workplace
Explain the importance of feedback mechanisms in leadership and team building.

core.title: Facilitating vs Directing People
core.description: Good leaders are predominantly facilitators, these leaders teach their people how to work effectively and solve problems. The result is more empowered and capable teams. Directing is said to be a process in which the managers instruct, guide, and oversee the performance of the employees to achieve predetermined goals.

metadata.summary: Learn to differentiate between a leader and a director and how to define an enabler.
learning_outcomes: Differentiate between a leader and a director
Define an enabler
Describe how a good leader facilitates an employee's problem solving ability

core.title: Executive Presence
core.description:
Executive presence isn’t something you’re born with, it’s a combination of learned behaviors and characteristics that can be developed. Depending upon your personality, industry, business goals and challenges, executive presence can be manifested in different ways.

Having great presentation skills and making a strong first impression based on your clothing and demeanor is not executive presence. You need more substantive abilities to face daily business challenges, speak your mind while maintaining your composure, or inspire your team to commit to a demanding new goal. Executive presence is a purposefully developed hybrid of internal character and external presentation. Let’s look at the qualities that distinguish great leaders from mediocre ones.

Accreditation

0.25 hours, Continuing Education Units (CEU) from the Society for Human Resource Management (SHRM)

0.25 hours, Continuing Education Units (CEU) from the HR Certificate Institute (HRCI)

Receive feedback in different forms
Develop your own executive presence

core.title: Everyone is a Leader
core.description: For a time, the Disney company got some of its best ideas from the janitor. Leadership can be seen in any role and from any person. Using application exercises and rich multimedia, learn how to identify leadership potential and how to use the influence of "unofficial" leaders to everyone"s benefit.

learning_outcomes: Recognize natural interests and skills that can be shared with others

core.title: Encouraging cooperation
core.description:
Do you know the example of a player who does not pass the ball to his companions, but tries to do everything by himself and is invariably stopped by the opposition of two or three opponents?

Have you ever said, or heard others say to you, "Well, if I have to explain how something has to be done, I prefer to just do it myself"?

We can do many things by ourselves, but when a problem or a task becomes too complex, it is better to deal with it together with others. This is what we will see in this pill, that will lead you from working to co-operating.

metadata.summary: From operating to cooperating. How to combine individual skills for productive teamwork.
learning_outcomes: Manage roles.
Obtain cooperation.

core.title: Emotional intelligence
core.description:
Course Description

Emotional intelligence is a transformative skill needed for working in teams or managing people. In this course we cover how emotional intelligence can be employed in your daily life as someone who works with others, we will also go over practical skills needed for emotional intelligence and how to form strong working relationships through these skills.

 

Course Duration

﻿15 minutes

Be aware of practical skills for understanding your emotions

core.title: Emotional Intelligence: The EI framework (Part 2 of 5)
core.description: Gain insights to the four Emotional Intelligence competencies and leadership skills developed through EI. Understand the two axis of the Emotional Intelligence framework. Learn what empathy is, how it differs from sympathy, and how to spot whether you’re an empathetic leader.

learning_outcomes: Explain the meaning of Empathy
Identify the EI framework
Distinguish the components of EI

core.title: Emotional Intelligence: Techniques to build EI skills (Part 5 of 5)

learning_outcomes: Improve your self-awareness
Build intra-personal skills for EI development
Build inter-personal skills for EI development

core.title: Emotional Intelligence: Practical steps to develop EI (Part 4 of 5)

core.title: Emotional Intelligence: Managing Emotions and Mindset (Part 3 of 5)
core.description:
The Emotional Intelligence skill of emotional self-management enables us to change our feelings from bad to good and vice versa. As a result, it is crucial for our ability to switch between growth and fixed mindsets, as well as for our mental and behavioral agility.

Understand how thoughts and emotions work together and how we manage our emotions by managing the thoughts that trigger the emotions.

learning_outcomes: Increasing your self-motivation
Understand and identify emotions and universal expressions of emotions

core.title: Emotional Intelligence: Defining and Understanding EI (Part 1 of 5)
core.description:
Emotional intelligence (otherwise known as emotional quotient or EQ) is the ability to understand, use, and manage your own emotions in positive ways to relieve stress, communicate effectively, empathize with others, overcome challenges and defuse conflict.

Understand what Emotional Intelligence is and is not, the four steps to understanding Emotional Intelligence and the importance on your career success.

learning_outcomes: Distinguish between what Emotional Intelligence is about and what it is not
Identify the main steps to Emotional Intelligence
Identify the connection between Emotional Intelligence and career success

core.title: Emotional Intelligence Strategies_3
core.description:
In the previous lessons, you have learned the four skills of self-awareness, self-management, social awareness, and relationship management to increase your EQ and strengthen your ability to manage yourself and influence others. Boosting your emotional intelligence will leverage your existing skills, IQ, personality, education, and experience even more. This should align with the benefits of increasing your EQ as a leader in terms of how they deal with their people and increase their leadership skills. Consider that you may have the best plan and strategy, but it will not matter unless you communicate this strategy to your team, persuade them to work on it, listen to their inputs, and guide them through the hurdles. You will be able to do this through an exhibition of strong EQ. In this lesson, we will outline some strategies, exercises, and ideas you can use to become an emotionally intelligent leader. You need people skills to execute and succeed in your plan. Developing your EQ will supercharge your leadership arsenal.

 

Accreditation

0.25 hours, Continuing Education Units (CEU) from the Society for Human Resource Management (SHRM)

0.25 hours, Continuing Education Units (CEU) from the HR Certificate Institute (HRCI)

Relationship management is considered to be the pinnacle of emotional intelligence.

core.title: Embracing New Ideas - Interactive
core.description:
(Updated Nov 2024)

Developing new ideas makes us creative. Sharing new ideas leads to innovation. This entertaining and stimulating interactive course is designed to help people develop skills and enthusiasm for being creative and innovative.

 

The Cutting Edge team learn to embrace new ideas. Marcus invites everyone to suggest innovations to enhance productivity and improve the culture. Junko and Alex compete and tension escalates when accusations are made about stealing ideas. Marcus and Michael present new ideas to the group that are received with varying degrees of success. Carol emphasizes that ideas should be shared. Michael’s innovation of micro bags is put into practice.

Key Learning Points

  • Don’t assume your ideas are best INSTEAD: Be open to everyone
  • Don’t accuse others of stealing ideas INSTEAD: Compliment and share
  • Don’t criticize INSTEAD: Listen and discuss
  • Don’t sit on good ideas INSTEAD: Voice ideas so they grow


Target Audience

All staff, Personal use, Managers, Executives


Comedy makes learning fun

This interactive course is part of the popular Cutting Edge Communication Comedy Series created by Psychologist Eve Ash and comedienne Erin Brown starring Emmy-award winning Kim Estes. This powerful training series follows several characters as they battle challenges, negotiate conflicts and learn from mistakes about professionalism, leadership, communication and safety. This Australian produced series was filmed on location in Los Angeles.

core.title: Digital Transformation - Change Management Right? (CPD Certified)
core.description:
Digital transformation is just a new ‘buzzword’ for change management, right? You only need to add some fancy apps, and you’re ready to go! Well... not exactly. Digital transformation does involve change management, but it has some very specific challenges.

For example, instead of 1 completed change, digital transformation is an ongoing process of never-ending change.
That means rethinking a traditional change-management approach. If you find yourself tasked with a mission to carry out a digital transformation in your organisation, we have some helpful techniques to make that digital transformation a success.

LEARNING OBJECTIVES:

  • Distinguish between change management and digital transformation, and choose which process to use in different scenarios for the most-effective results
  • Adapt change-management strategies for digital transformation to maximise the chance of success
  • Implement techniques to make digital transformation a success

WHY SHOULD I TAKE THIS COURSE?

This course would suit anyone involved in organising a digital transformation, particularly if you work in change management or human resources. You’ll be able to see what makes digital transformation different to change management, adapt your change strategies, and use the right approach to make digital transformation a success.

learning_outcomes: Distinguish between change management and digital transformation, and choose which process to use in different scenarios for the most-effective results
Adapt change-management strategies for digital transformation to maximise the chance of success
Implement techniques to make digital transformation a success

core.title: Diffusing Anger - Interactive
core.description:
(Updated Nov 2024)

It’s easy to escalate anger. It’s a skill to dissipate anger and remain calm. An entertaining interactive course designed to provide practical ways to handle difficult people and conflict situations at work, and reduce anger and complaints, whether it be colleagues or customers.

 

Marcus runs a training session to help staff manager anger and invites Serena as the anger management expert which makes Carol angry. Marcus uses a toy crocodile and some boxing kangaroos to get the messages across but when Michael and Sam are asked to demonstrate their anger management skills the role-play escalates into an embarrassing situation.

Key Learning Point

  • Don't bottle up anger INSTEAD: Calmly explain how you feel
  • Don’t react to anger with anger INSTEAD: Rise above and stay rational
  • Don’t get stuck on emotions INSTEAD: Be empathic and move forward
  • Don’t walk away without resolution INSTEAD: Find common ground and resolve

Comedy makes learning fun

This interactive course is part of the popular Cutting Edge Communication Comedy Series created by Psychologist Eve Ash and comedienne Erin Brown starring Emmy-award winning Kim Estes. This powerful training series follows several characters as they battle challenges, negotiate conflicts and learn from mistakes about professionalism, leadership, communication and safety. core.title: Delegation Techniques
core.description:
About this course: Delegation is a skill. It is sharing authority and responsibility as a team leader with the team members. But delegating does not mean dumping personal responsibility on to others. Delegating tasks can lighten your workload. There is a proverb that says, “The more heads working together, the better”. Because we both know we have unique skills. There are things you can do that others can’t do and vice versa. Delegating tasks allows team members to learn new skills and develop a sense of responsibility. Employees who feel that they are trusted and respected tend to have a higher level of commitment to their work, their organisation, and, especially, their managers. Remember that delegating empowers your team and builds trust.
Once the session is completed, you will be able to define the meaning of delegation, identify tips in delegating tasks effectively and adopt the strategies leaders must use to delegate tasks effectively for the success of the team.

core.title: Controlling your emotions
core.description:
In corporate life we sometimes encounter situations where changes tension and stress can make us lose our composure even though it is precisely at this moment that we most require emotional stability. The aim of this module is to provide you with tools to deal with these situations. 

This course will cover:

  • Understanding why self-control is vital.
  • Using tools for managing emotions.
  • Using positive thinking.

Target Audience

Anyone who wants to develop high-quality human relationships within the workplace.

Accreditation

PMI accreditation: earn 0.5 PDU points from PMI.

metadata.summary: Physical and breathing exercises to keep emotions at bay and better understand how they work.
learning_outcomes: Establish practical ways to manage your emotions over time
How to use positive thinking to deal with tension and better control your emotions

core.title: Constructive Feedback
core.description:
About this course: Providing feedback means giving your team an explanation of what they are doing correctly and incorrectly. Giving negative feedback to your team can be tricky. You need to make it constructive. You’re looking for improvements so don’t ignore problems hoping they will sort themselves out. There are several types of feedback but today, we will focus on constructive feedback. So, what is constructive feedback? Constructive feedback is supportive feedback given to individuals to help identify solutions to areas of weakness they may have. Therefore, it comes with positive intentions and is used as a supportive communication tool to address specific issues or concerns. Remember that the best way to approach telling someone about their work or even behaviour is to be direct and make sure it’s about work or behaviour, not in any way personal. 
Once the session is completed, you will be able to explain the meaning of constructive feedback, identify the tips in giving constructive feedback and employ effective constructive feedback techniques for the team and for successful leadership.

learning_outcomes: Explain the meaning of constructive feedback
Identify the tips in giving constructive feedback
Employ effective constructive feedback techniques for the team and for successful leadership.

core.title: Conflict Resolution
core.description:
Course Overview 

Conflict is something we have all experienced on more than one occasion. It can trigger strong emotions and can lead to hurt feelings, distress and anxiety.

It can also manifest into personal dislike. Teamwork can evaporate, focus can be lost, and in a workplace environment, this can be disastrous.

However, conflict dealt with correctly can create vastly improved outcomes for all concerned.

Course consists of 6 minutes of video content combined with assessment questions and interactivity.

 

Learning Objectives

By completing this video based eLearning program, your managers and staff will learn:

  • How misunderstandings can lead to conflict
  • The impact conflict can have on individual relationships at work and on the workplace in general
  • Strategies for achieving win/win outcomes

They will learn how to resolve conflict in the workplace with a range of highly effective and easy to apply techniques.

 

Target Audience

Aimed at all staff, but espeically managers and supervisors.

 

Business Outcomes

A great tool for creating a more harmonious, stress free working environment.

 

Duration

10 to 15 mins

core.title: Conflict Management (CPD certified)
core.description:
“HANDS OFF, this is MINE. If I find out who has been stealing my yoghurts, there will be SEVERE repercussions!” “Don’t look at me, I’m lactose-intolerant.”

Ah, the office. A shared fridge is a breeding ground for passive-aggressive notes, it seems. The thing is, a modern office often contains a mix of personalities and cultures. Whilst diversity is a brilliant thing in itself, hiring people from all walks of life can lead to some conflicts in the workplace if those cultures collide. With our guidance, you can take control of your office to help mitigate any conflicts and help prevent them in the future.

What does this course cover: -

  • How to handle conflict at work?
  • Accommodating different personality types
  • How to prevent conflicts from occurring?

Why should I take this course?

Happy staff are productive staff. When you all work together to eliminate conflict within the workplace, your business can continue to flourish. Conflict can have a detrimental effect on productivity and morale, so it’s best to sort it out quickly and effectively.

learning_outcomes: How to handle conflict at work
Accommodating different personality types
How to prevent conflicts from occurring
This course is CPD certified

core.title: Competition vs. Differentiation (SWOT Analysis)
core.description:
Consistent business analysis is critical to a company’s short- and long-term success. Because the SWOT framework is such a simple, flexible, and powerful tool, organizations can use it to examine, plan, and implement business decisions and plans that range from incremental to comprehensive. By gathering a range of input from inside and outside the organization, your analysis will provide substantial, relevant, and objective data to guide your decision-making. Whether you’re planning new corporate-wide strategic goals or reviewing departmental processes, a well-executed SWOT analysis will enable you to focus on your strengths, diminish threats, and take advantage of identified business and market opportunities as you move forward.

core.title: Communicate Effectively to Improve Collaboration - Part 1
core.description: Everything is communication: even when we are not actually speaking in a meeting, the way we behave has a meaning that will be interpreted by our interlocutor. Because communication errors create tension and are a waste of energy, the ability to communicate well is an essential skill that everyone must cultivate carefully. It is important for the person transmitting information to convey a clear, unambiguous message correctly, and for the receiver to facilitate the transmission, providing feedback on the way the message is perceived, and making sure that the information is complete. Take this course to learn how to improve your understanding and make yourself clearly understood.

core.title: Cognitive biases: thinking traps - Part 2
core.description: Why do we value a 10-euro note that we find down the back of the sofa more than a banknote in our wallet? Why do we prefer to hire a candidate who is similar to us, even though we might miss out on a rare gem? Quite simply because our reasoning is disturbed by cognitive bias in daily life. To break free of these mechanisms, we need to understand them. If you can recognise yourself in these examples, then this training course is for you!

core.title: Coaching Vs. Mentoring
core.description:
Mentoring is a process that follows coaching. Coaching makes a person equipped with the skills required for a job whereas mentoring is on-the-job process. It helps a person practice the skills learned, enhance the skills, and learn new skills to be future ready. Hence, coaching is a short-term relationship whereas mentoring is a long-term. Coaching is always task oriented whereas mentoring is relationship oriented. It is all about reaching a stage where the mentor can easily share the real issues influencing the trainee. On the other hand, coaching can be implemented immediately on any particular topic. This course will help you acknowledge the difference between coaching and mentoring and make you learn when to use them.


Accreditation

core.title: Coaching Techniques
core.description:
Coaching is more than just a word of encouragement. The principles are all simple. It is about unlocking the potential in your team. Identifying strengths and weaknesses and getting the best from individuals to achieve better results. It is about improving performance, and the quicker it happens, the better. A good coach knows what is required to do a job well, not just well but to exceed expectations. 
To do that, a leader must be willing to pay attention to the details and identify what are good and bad techniques. If staff happen to make mistakes then offer training solutions. It is important to keep records of what is being said within your team. The actions carried out and the plan to put in place. This helps you track any progress and the records you keep are useful for evaluation and follow up meetings. 
Importantly, you must turn this process into a positive about improving performance, not finding faults.
Once the session is completed, you will be able to describe good coaching techniques, identify reasons why employees fail to perform and solutions to the problems. Also, you’ll be able to provide a list of key points to achieve a better environment for the team.

Provide a list of key points to achieve a better environment for the team.

core.description:
Your talent is your most important resource. Deploying it to implement different methods of coaching will not only help you to strengthen your team’s abilities, but also your own leadership skills. No matter where you are, no matter how many people you put together on a team, you will always experience the same phenomenon. Some team members will perform above expectations while others will perform at an average or standard level, and some will perform at substandard levels. Coaching is a performance process with lots of actions and steps. Let’s take a look at some of the ways to coach your team and how you can make the most of these opportunities.

core.title: Clarifying and managing your priorities - Part B
core.description:
In today's business world the leading cause of stress is a feeling that there is not sufficient time to get everything done. Each and every day you field multiple requests from different people requiring you to perform different duties simultaneously and wanting everything done instantly.

It is difficult to prioritize make the right decisions and find the right balance between your professional and personal life.

This course will cover:

  • Clarifying the priorities of your position.
  • Using the multiplying factors method to focus on what is essential while preserving your energy.

Target Audience

Prerequisites

core.title: Choosing A Leadership Theory
core.description:
Social scientists have studied and designed leadership theories for decades to understand and explain how great leaders are made. They have compiled lists of leadership traits and constructed frameworks and models to illustrate the leadership phenomenon. And while these theories are detailed, thoroughly researched, and insightful, none provide “the” singular leadership model that works for every high-level manager aspiring to lead their team effectively and successfully.

What they do provide is an abundant source of leadership data that can be used to create your own flexible brand of leadership. Leaders face a wide range of tasks, responsibilities, and challenges—both anticipated and unexpected—every day.

Assembling a toolkit of leadership options that can address them is something smart leaders do. Let’s study the specifics of some core leadership theories and how you might use them in different business scenarios.

Accreditation

0.25 hours, Continuing Education Units (CEU) from the HR Certificate Institute (HRCI)

core.title: Change Management - Part 3
core.description: Over its lifetime, a company is bound to evolve and transform itself, to adjust to its wider environment. The discipline that allows these transformations to be carried out seamlessly, placing the employees at the heart of the process, is known as “change management”. This course details the key stages andsine qua non conditions for conducting successful change, and sets out all the reasons why it is essential to consider the human factor no longer as an obstacle, but as the major asset and driving force of any transformation.

core.title: Business Acumen
core.description:
Business acumen is gaining an understanding of how business works as well as the behaviors business professionals should possess. This important skill is critical not only to corporate leaders, but to aspiring leaders, managers, and employees as well. The organization that prioritizes business acumen as a core competency promotes the growth of its workforce and strengthens its competitive edge.
Some use the analogy of a quarterback who can “see” the entire field to describe business acumen. It’s simply understanding how your company operates, and then using that knowledge to develop the best business strategy. Regardless of your role in the organization, it’s an important skill to develop.

core.title: Building an Effective Leadership Succession Plan
core.description:
How much time do you spend developing your leadership succession plan? As older leaders begin to retire at greater rates, the 2018 Deloitte Millennial Survey discovered that 65% of potential millennial leaders feel unprepared to take their places. Forbes reports that by 2025, 75% of the workforce will be made up of millennials. These statistics suggest that there’s a leadership crisis on the horizon. Designing a strategy and framework to direct leadership development is mission critical for every organization. Training—and retaining —emerging leaders in your company should be a top priority. Understanding what team members want and expect from an employer will help you develop the right programs and systems to keep your talent engaged in learning, growing, and contributing to your organization.

core.title: Building Relationships - Interactive
core.description:
(Updated Dec 2024)

Building positive relationships at work is important. Relationships can positively or negatively affect work performance and job satisfaction. Good relationships are essential for success at work. They can lead to greater recognition in your job and improved personal motivation. In this amusing case study from the Cutting Edge team, Marcus sets up a "speed socializing" exercise to give staff an insight into building long lasting relationships. Steve is chosen as the relationship expert to comment on the relationship skill level of this team mates. Tammy and Sanjay's awkward interaction escalates when Steve refers to him as a narcissist and Tammy gets angry with everyone.

Learn that trust, communication and respect are key to building positive relationships with people at work. Good relationships can make your work more satisfying and more productive.

 

Key Learning Points

  • Don’t tune out and get bored INSTEAD: Ask interesting questions
  • Don’t make judgments or assume INSTEAD: Listen and be open
  • Don’t be defensive or argue INSTEAD: Be calm and controlled
  • Don’t give up on people you dislike INSTEAD: Find common ground

Comedy makes learning fun

This interactive course is part of the popular Cutting Edge Communication Comedy Series created by Psychologist Eve Ash and comedienne Erin Brown starring Emmy-award winning Kim Estes. This powerful training series follows several characters as they battle challenges, negotiate conflicts and learn from mistakes about professionalism, leadership, communication and safety. This Australian produced series was filmed on location in Los Angeles.

core.title: Building Innovation Teams
core.description:
"If you always do what you always did, you will always get what you always got " - Albert Einstein Innovation by itself is a challenging and draining process. The unpredictability of the results of innovation adds to the stress of the innovator or innovation teams. Combining the task of innovation with a predictable process helps ease out the difficulties. This lesson focuses on the six areas which can be included in your innovation plan framework that will help you conduct the innovative team building activities in a constructive manner. You will also be in a position to identify the innovation roles and appoint the right persons to promote a flawless innovation process. Organizations that innovate new concepts using the correct framework and processes can ensure consistent industry growth. Take this lesson to learn about building innovation teams.

core.title: Building Emotional Intelligence_2
core.description:
Your success as a leader isn’t dependent upon how much technical knowledge, business expertise, or years of industry experience you have. If you want to achieve goals consistently, build strong, collaborative teams, and establish solid relationships with colleagues, superiors, and clients, then you need Emotional Intelligence (EQ). Emotional Intelligence, also known as Emotional Quotient (EQ) is the ability to properly gauge your emotions as well as the emotions of others in all situations, use proper judgment and behave appropriately for the desired outcome. In other words, EQ is the ability to identify your emotions, and those of others, and use that knowledge to make the best decisions, regardless of the circumstances.

 

Accreditation

0.25 hours, Continuing Education Units (CEU) from the HR Certificate Institute (HRCI)

core.title: Briefings
core.description:
About this course: For team leaders, a daily briefing is an effective way to start a day. They are often carried out informally way. Team briefings are essential and bring benefits to the team. They prevent rumours spreading. They are also designed to bring teams together, discuss issues and increase productivity in the workplace. 
The team leader should focus on the performance of the team. Motivate your team members with praise. Remember, all meetings and briefings should of course be two-way. The team must actively listen as much as talk. Make it as fun as possible. 
Once the session is completed, you will be able to define team briefings, identify key points to talk about during briefings, and create actions for successful team briefings.
